_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Goforth Processing Plant (Goforth) utilizes more than the threshold quantity of a ?regulated flammable substance (10,000 pounds)? in the processing of natural gas, where natural gas liquids (NGL) are extracted from the inlet gas using a propane refrigeration process and treated by an amine unit prior to being delivered to the pipeline for further market distribution. Therefore, this facility is subject to the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements codified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 (40 CFR 68) administered by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).

The Goforth is a newly constructed facility; therefore, it has not had an accidental release of a regulated substance where exposure to the substance, its reaction products, overpressure generated by an explosion involving the substance, or radiant heat generated by a fire involving the substance led to any off-site death, injury, or response or restoration activities for an exposure of an environmental receptor. In addition, the estimated flammable endpoint for a worst-case release is less than the distance to any public or environmental receptor. Furthermore, emergency response procedures have been coordinated between the facility and local emergency planning and response organizations. Therefore, Goforth Processing Plant is subject to Program 1 requirements as stated in 40 CFR 68.10. 

At the initial stages of operation, Goforth will employ four (4) full-time employees on-site who will ensure the proper operation and maintenance of the facility. 

The following information summarizes the Goforth 2006 RMP submission.  

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Goforth maintains a policy of safe NGL extraction operations, reducing to the greatest extent possible hazards associated with the extraction processes, and reducing subsequent risk to the surrounding community, employees, and the environment.   

Goforth has procedures in place, including both on-site activiti

es and coordination with off-site responders that are to be followed in the event of a NGL release.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Goforth processes NGL in various aboveground vessels and associated piping and valves. NGL is a regulated flammable mixture that is an aliphatic and aromatic hydrocarbon mixture. The regulated flammable chemicals contained in the NGL mixture include methane, ethane, propane, isobutane, N-butane, isopentane, and N-pentane. The maximum inventory of NGL at Goforth at any given time is 5,528 gallons (22,874 lbs). Goforth also utilizes propane, a regulated flammable substance, as part of the process. The propane is handled in various aboveground vessels and associated piping and valves. The maximum inventory of propane at Goforth is at any given time 5,842 gallons (24,572 lbs).

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Goforth has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements of 40 CFR 68.180. Goforth maintains written Emergency Shutdown and Startup Procedures (ESSP) that provide guidance for emergencies expected at the facility. Further safety information is also detailed in the ESSP. In addition, operating procedures and equipment design codes and standards associated with the operations at the facility are maintained. 

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENTAL HISTORY

Goforth is a newly constructed facility. For this reason, no accidental releases of NGL or propane occurred that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or any environmental impact for the period of five (5) years prior to March 2006.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Emergency Response Program is documented in the facility?s Emergency Shutdown and Startup Procedures, which describes response procedures to minimize hazards to human health and the environment in the event of a regu

lated substance accidental release. The facility has coordinated the emergency response and plan with the Parker County LEPC and the Benbrook Fire Department.  The Benbrook Fire Department is designated as the first responder in the event of NGL and/or propane release.  

A site map, MSDSs, and a list of chemicals kept on-site are maintained at the facility.  

SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS

Maintenance checks, compliance audits, management of change procedures, and incident investigations will identify changes to improve safety. Goforth has a continued commitment to update equipment and improve safety pertaining to the covered process when necessary.
